dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: ...I mean, a fully unmanned eighteen-wheeler, on a U.S. highway. Like, the first time ever. That's, uh, a massive step, don't you think?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: ...I mean, a fully unmanned eighteen-wheeler, on a U.S. highway. Like, the first time ever. That's, uh, a massive step, don't you think?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starsky Robotics, a San Francisco startup trying to commercialize automated truck technology, said its the first company to test an unmanned 18-wheeler on a stretch of U.S. highway... This is literally the first time anyone has taken the person out of the vehicle on public highway, Seltz-Axmacher told Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Unmanned, but still had a human, like, with a joystick somewhere. So, um, how 'unmanned' was it, really?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Unmanned, but still had a human, like, with a joystick somewhere. So, um, how 'unmanned' was it, really?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: ...it so by combining an onboard self-driving system with a remote operator standing by to guide the vehicle when necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It was a remote operator for emergencies, yeah, but the truck itself was navigating. Autonomously. Even merged onto the Florida Turnpike, changed lanes, fifty-five miles an hour, even in a hailstorm.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It was a remote operator for emergencies, yeah, but the truck itself was navigating. Autonomously. Even merged onto the Florida Turnpike, changed lanes, fifty-five miles an hour, even in a hailstorm.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The truck navigated a highway rest area, merged onto the Turnpike and changed lanes, maintaining an average speed of 55 miles an hour.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Florida. The land of, like, straight roads. And, uh, hailstorms, I guess. But remote control? What about latency? That's, you know, a real issue.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Florida. The land of, like, straight roads. And, uh, hailstorms, I guess. But remote control? What about latency? That's, you know, a real issue.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Competitors dont rely on remote operation, citing concerns about latency, the potential for delays in cell signal transmission.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They address that! They use the teleoperations mostly at lower speeds, for tricky situations where latency isn't, uh, a major problem. It's a backup.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They address that! They use the teleoperations mostly at lower speeds, for tricky situations where latency isn't, uh, a major problem. It's a backup.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starskys system uses teleoperations mainly at lower speeds and in situations where latency isnt an issue.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's not really fully autonomous then, is it? Just... mostly. With an expensive, um, video game setup.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's not really fully autonomous then, is it? Just... mostly. With an expensive, um, video game setup.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The remote operator sits in front of a bank of video monitors that show everything the trucks cameras see. Theres a small, video-game-style steering wheel, accelerator and brake pedals and other controls that let operators take over when necessary.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But it's the first time anyone has completely removed the driver from the vehicle on a public highway. That's what the CEO told Forbes! It's pivotal!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's the first time anyone has completely removed the driver from the vehicle on a public highway. That's what the C E O told Forbes! It's pivotal!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is literally the first time anyone has taken the person out of the vehicle on public highway, Seltz-Axmacher told Forbes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Pivotal, sure. Until it hits, like, a flock of migrating geese, and suddenly 'latency' becomes, uh, a very big problem for those, you know, emergency controls.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pivotal, sure. Until it hits, like, a flock of migrating geese, and suddenly 'latency' becomes, uh, a very big problem for those, you know, emergency controls.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They actually mentioned geese! They've built it to handle that! And get this, they're already generating half a million dollars a month hauling loads. Like, avocados from California!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They actually mentioned geese! They've built it to handle that! And get this, they're already generating half a million dollars a month hauling loads. Like, avocados from California!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Were in the neighborhood of half a million dollars a month, Seltz-Axmacher said... The company operates as a conventional trucking service, hauling loads in Florida and elsewhere

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Avocados. Right. Because that's the pinnacle of, um, technological achievement. Remotely-steered guacamole ingredients.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Avocados. Right. Because that's the pinnacle of, um, technological achievement. Remotely-steered guacamole ingredients.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: No, but seriously, this differentiates them from Waymo, from TuSimple. They're making money now while developing the tech. That's, uh, smart.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, but seriously, this differentiates them from Waymo, from TuSimple. They're making money now while developing the tech. That's, uh, smart.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starsky also differs from rivals in that the company operates as a conventional trucking service, hauling loads in Florida and elsewhere often relying solely on human drivers. As a result, its now generating revenue that helps fund ongoing development of its high-tech trucks

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So it's just, what, a glorified Uber for trucks then? With, like, a glorified PlayStation controller attached?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So it's just, what, a glorified Uber for trucks then? With, like, a glorified PlayStation controller attached?

dialogue_turns.text: It's groundbreaking tech! It's already operational, and it means the future of logistics is, uh, way closer than you think!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's groundbreaking tech! It's already operational, and it means the future of logistics is, uh, way closer than you think!

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, yeah. More robots, fewer jobs. Always the way these things go.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, yeah. More robots, fewer jobs. Always the way these things go.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But they employ eighty people! Almost half are drivers! It's an evolution, not, like, a straight replacement!
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But they employ eighty people! Almost half are drivers! It's an evolution, not, like, a straight replacement!
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The company has a fleet of 40 trucks, both automated and non-automated, and 80 employees, about half of whom are truck drivers.
